brief_summary.textblock:
Background: Kinesiotaping (KT) is an elastic therapeutic tape developed in the 70's by Dr
      Kenso Kase for prevention and treatment of sports injuries. Research shows that through
      activation of skin receptors KT improves blood and lymph flow, increases proprioception,
      helps relieve pain, facilitates joint and muscle alignment, and enhances muscle function.
      Despite the increasing popularity of KT, uncertainty remains regarding, in particular, its
      effectiveness in improving strength.

      Purpose: The purpose of the current study was to investigate the short-term effects of KT on
      muscle strength when applied to the quadriceps muscles of healthy subjects.

      Methods: A randomized controlled trial with 52 healthy subjects was conducted. Subjects were
      tested under four different conditions: a) facilitating Kinesiotape, b) inhibiting
      Kinesiotape, c) classical tape with no elastic properties, and d) no-taping across four
      different sessions. The parameters of interest were: quadriceps and hamstrings maximal
      strength and power using vertical jump tests (squat jump and countermovement jump), and peak
      concentric and eccentric knee torque (using isokinetic test protocol).

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Kinesiotape on Quadriceps and Hamstring Muscle Strength

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  at least 18 years of age

          -  allowed to perform jumps

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  pregnancy

          -  history of cardio-vascular disease

          -  antecedents of lower extremity injuries

          -  use of any doping substances listed by the World Anti-doping Agency

          -  any contraindication to exercise

facility.name: Unite d'orthopédie et traumatologie du sport

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Kinesiotape on Quadriceps and Hamstring Muscle Strength

oversight_info.authority: Switzerland: Federal Office of Public Health

primary_outcome.measure: Vertical jump height change with different tapes

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Isokinetic knee strength change with different tapes

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
